$GOOGL just dropped its 7th-gen TPU ‚ÄòIronwood‚Äô & it‚Äôs a monster.

It‚Äôs built for massive AI workloads & plugs directly into Google Cloud which gives them full control over how their models are trained & deployed.

The shift to AI-driven compute means hyperscalers aren‚Äôt renting GPUs anymore so they‚Äôre building their own silicon to train faster and run cheaper.

Whoever owns the hardware owns the economics of AI & compute is the new currency.

I opened two new positions this week in the growth portfolio. 

Both companies are under $2B in market cap. Any guesses?

$NVDA CEO Jensen Huang said AI demand continues to accelerate ‚Äúmonth by month‚Äù and that he‚Äôs asked $TSM for more wafer supply. 

Speaking in Taiwan, he emphasized TSMC‚Äôs importance to Nvidia‚Äôs success, saying, ‚ÄúNo TSMC, no Nvidia.‚Äù

$BN CEO Bruce Flatt, who oversees over $1T in assets across real estate, infrastructure & energy, says we‚Äôre not in a bubble but we‚Äôre entering a build cycle.

He emphasized that the companies driving this era have balance sheets stronger than many nations & are locking in long-duration, hard assets with 10+ years of cash flow visibility at fixed financing costs.

Between AI compute demand, electrification & population growth the global power capacity will need to expand by over 25K terawatt-hours in the next 15 years.

The market keeps calling it overvalued but the truth is we‚Äôre underbuilt.

What the market hears:

I think you can reduce 80 percent of culture wars to questions of economics‚Äîlike a libertarian or a Marxist would‚Äîand then you can reduce maybe 80 percent of economic questions to questions of real estate. --- Peter Thiel
---
He is correct, detailed here

Here is the problem in one chart.

Non-homeowners do not make enough money to qualify for a mortgage. They make it work by extending themselves through borrowing the down payment (from family/friends) or assistance programs.

50-year mortgages and/or Fed rate cuts are not going to get the orange (qualifying income) and blue (median income) to converge.

What will get them to converge is lower home prices.

The problem is that 86 million homeowners in the United States do not want lower home prices.

Great, "innovative" mortgage financing is returning!n (repost)

Anyone remember these "innovations" leading into the 2007/2008 financial crisis ...

* NINJA Loans and "Liar Loans" ("No Income, No Job, Approved,")

* Adjustable-Rate Mortgages (ARMs)

* Interest-Only and Negative Amortization Loans

* 100% and ‚ÄúOver 100%‚Äù Loan-to-Value Loans

* Alt-A and Option ARM Loans
---
What the public needs is LOWER home prices. To accomplish that, you need ALL home prices to go down, meaning current homeowners have to take a (unrealized) loss.

Mortgage innovation is an acknowledgment that home prices are too high and unaffordable for the average first-time homebuyer (chart).

Instead of lowering prices, we stand on our heads to find ways for non-homebuyers to "afford" current prices through innovations in mortgage finance.

How did that work out?
Ferguson‚Äôs Law: Any great power that spends more on debt than on defense is likely to cease being a great power.

Microsoft $MSFT added that this translated to 15,200 tokens/s per $NVDA Blackwell Ultra GPU, a 27% increase from 12,022 tokens/s for Blackwell GPUs.

Microsoft $MSFT said that it achieved an aggregated 1.1 million token/s on one $NVDA GB300 NLV72 rack, a new record in inference throughput, beating its own prior record of 865,000 tokens/s on the GB200.

TSMC $TSM is rumored to be considering four-year consecutive price hike for its <5nm nodes, with average price hikes of 3% to 5% per year.
